**Title:** Incidence of Caseating Granulomas in Cutaneous Leishmaniasis: A Multicenterial Cohort Study

**Research Question:** What is the incidence of caseating granulomas in cutaneous leishmanias (CL) and how do they differ from other granuloma types in terms of geographical distribution, histology, and healing time to resolution?

**Methods:** A multicenter cohort study of 317 patients with CL from Syria (157), Pakistan (66), Lebanon (47), Saudi Arabia (43), Ethiopia (2), and Iran (2) was conducted. Clinical data on age, sex, disease duration, lesion type, and geographic and anatomic location, and microscopic data on presence and type of granuloma, Ridley's parasitic index (PI) and pattern (RP) were documented. Microorganisms were evaluated using special stains (GMS, PAS, AFB, and Gram) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for TB and CL. All cases were confirmed by PCR followed by restriction length polymorphism analysis for molecular speciation and negative for other organisms.

**Findings:** Granulomas were identified in 195 (61.5%) of CL cases, divided into caseating (25.2%), suppurative (4.6%), and tuberculoid necrosis (70.2%). Caseating and tuboid granuloma groups differed significantly in terms of geographical distribution, with more cases in Saudi Arabia (p<0.0001). Histologically, both groups differed in distribution of RP (p<0.000) with RP3 in caseating granulomas (31% vs 15%) and RP5 in tuboid granuloma (38 vs 19%). Time to healing (RP) was shorter in tuboid vs case (4.0 vs 6.2 months). Parasitic index, species, and other variables did not differ between granuloma groups.

**Implications:** This study documents an 18.2% incidence of caseating granulomas in CL, suggesting CL should be part of differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions. Cases with caseating granulomas showed slower healing, no association with species, possibly due to worse immune response or more aggressive leish strains.

**Conclusion:** This study highlights the importance of considering CL in differential diagnosis for caseating granulomas in endemic regions, especially in regions included in this cohort, also endemic for TB.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the research article:

**Title:** Identification of Zinc Finger Transcription Factor Zfp69 as a Candidate Gene for the Diabetogenic Effect of QTL Nidd/SJ in Mouse Models of Obesity-Associated Diabetes

**Research Question:** What is the genetic basis of the diabetogenic effect of QTL Nidd/SJ in mouse models of obesity-associated diabetes?

**Methods:** We employed interval-specific congenic introgression of SJ into diabetes-resistant C57/BL/6 and subsequent cross with NZO to identify a critical interval on distal chromosome 4 (2.1 Mb) conferring the diabetic phenotype. We analyzed 10 genes in the interval by sequencing, qRT-PCR, and RACE-PCR, revealing a striking allelic variance of Zfp encoding zinc finger transcription factor 69.

**Findings:** In NZ and C57/6, a retrotranson IAP1 in intron 3 disrupted the gene formation of a truncated mRNA lacking the coding for KR (Krüpp-associated) and Znf2 domains Zfp, whereas diogenic SJ, NON, and B alleles generated a normal mRNA. The diogenic ZfpSJ allele produced hyperglycemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma triglyceride levels. The human orthologue Zfp, Z642, was significantly increased in adipose tissue from patients with type 2 diabetes.

**Implications:** Zfp is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of N/SJ, and retrotranson I1 contributes to genetic heterogeneity of strains. Expression of transcription in adipose tissue may play a role in pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.

**Conclusions:** Positional cloning of diabetes genes may provide insights into pathogenesis of obesity-associated diabetes. We previously identified QTL Nidd on dist chromosome 4 that aggravated and accelerated diabetes in outcross of NZ with SJ. This Q exhibited high scores for trait glucose and reproducibly doubled prevalence in NZxSJ backcross. The data identify Zfp as likely candidate for diogenic effect of QTL Nidd, which aggravates and accelerates obesity-associated diabetes in NZ and enhances hyperglyemia in B6/ob mice.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Predicting Mammalian Cell Differentiation: An Integrated Model of Regulatory and Signalling Pathways in the Vertebrate Hematopoietic System

**Research Question:** Despite the understanding of specific signals and transcription factors, predicting mammalian cell differentiation remains a daunting challenge. The vertebrate hematopoietic system, with its complex branching pathways and cell types, presents a compelling case study.

**Methods:** We propose an integrated model of regulatory and signalling pathways controlling cell differentiation. Due to the size and complexity of the network, we employ an original reduction approach with a stable identification algorithm. To assess effects of heterogeneous environments on cell differentiation, we perform systematic simulations considering prototypic environments.

**Findings:** We identify stable states corresponding to canonical Th1, Th2, Th, and Treg subtypes, coexisting with transient hybrid types co-expressing combinations of Th, Th, Treg, and Th17 markers in environment-dependent fashion. Our analysis highlights the nature of these types and relationships with canonical subtypes.

**Implications:** Our model can explore novel pathways in silico, assuming cross-inhibiting master factors generate canonical subtypes, precluding cell plasticity.

**Conclusions:**

Our integrated model provides a comprehensive understanding of regulatory and signalling pathways controlling Th differentiation. Using a qualitative formalism, we perform dynamical analyses on available qualitative data. The model reduction approach allows us to cope with the size and complexity of the network, while the stable identification algorithm assesses the effects of heterogeneous environments on cell differentiation. We identify stable states corresponding to canonical Th, Th, Th, and Treg subtypes, coexisting with transient hybrid types coexpressing combinations of Th, Th, T, and Th markers in environment-dependent fashion. Our analysis highlights the nature of these types and their relationships with canonical subtypes. The model can be used to explore novel pathways in silico, assuming crosshibiting master factors generate canonical subtypes, precluding cell plasticity.

**Title:** Elucidating the Mechanisms of Transcription Factor Binding: A Thermodynamic Modeling of Early Embryonic Anterior Patterning in Drosila

**Research Question:** How do transcription factors drive complex patterns of gene expression during animal development by binding to thousands of genomic regions, with quantitative differences in binding across regions mediating their activity?

**Methods:** We employed a thermodynamic model of transcription factor binding to evaluate the contribution of biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of early embryonic-posterior patterning in Drosila melanogaster. Predictions based on DNA and protein affinities alone achieved a correlation of ∼0.4 with experimental measurements in vivo. Incorporating cooperativity and competition among factors, and accounting for patterning by binding in every nucleus, had little effect on accuracy. A major source of error was prediction of events not occurring in vivo, hypothesized to reflect reduced chromatin accessibility.

**Findings:** Incorporating experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility into our model effectively predicted binding to regions of open chromatin, dramatically improving predictions to correlation 0.6-0.9 for various factors across target genes. Our results show that in open chromatin, binding can be predicted exclusively by sequence of individual factors, with minimal role interactions.

**Implications:** A combination of experimentally determined chromatin data and simple models of transcription binding may predict the landscape of any transcription factor with precision.

**Conclusions:** This study provides a practical method for predicting transcription factor binding and a platform to understand forces shaping quantitative variation in binding individual to regions of chromatin. We applied the model to predict genome-wide binding across 4,251 genes with expression data, finding a strong relation between model's ability to predict binding and gene expression level.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Regulation of Cell Proliferation by Daughterless and Extramacchaetea in Drosophila Epithelial Cells

**Research Question:** How do the basic helix-loop helix (bHL) transcription factors, specifically Daughterless (Da) and Extramacchaetea (Em), regulate cell proliferation in Drosila epithelial cells, and what is the underlying mechanism of this regulatory activity?

**Methods:** We employed genetic analysis to investigate the role of Da and Em in controlling the G2/M transition and cell proliferation inros epithelial cells of the imaginal discs.

**Findings:** Our results show that Em is required to downregulate Da, which in turn triggers mitosis via transcriptional activation of the universally conserved cell cycle component Cdc25. Ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced levels of Em or high levels of Da is sufficient to rescue proliferative defects in mutant cells. Moreover, we present evidence that Da acts as a transcriptional repressor of string.

**Implications:** This study defines a mechanism through which Em controls cell proliferation by regulating the activity of Da, which transcriptionally represses string. Our findings provide new insights into the role of proteins in cell cycle regulation, specifically inrosila, and highlight the importance of understanding these factors in physiological and pathological conditions, such as cancer.

**Conclusions:** This study reveals a novel mechanism by which Da and Em regulate cell cycle progression inrosila epithelial cells. Our model suggests that Em is required to downregulate Da, which in turn triggers mitosis via transcriptional activation of Cdc25, a universally conserved cell cycle component. These findings have implications for understanding the balance between proliferation and differentiation in the nervous system and other cell types.

**Title:** Elucidating Signaling Networks through Reversible Phosphorylation: A Comprehensive Analysis of the Phosphoproteome in Saccharomyces cerevisiae

**Research Question:** How do reversible phosphorylation events contribute to signaling networks regulating cell growth and development in Saccharomy cerevisiae, and what are the key proteins involved in these pathways?

**Methods:** We employed Stable Isotope Labeling with Amino acids in Cell (SILAC) technique to generate phosphoprote data from interventional kinase-dead mutants in Saccharomy cerevisiae. Our pipeline consisted of phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation analysis, and causal discovery to identify key proteins, protein interactions, and signaling networks.

**Findings:** We identified 5 high-confidence proteins from meta-analysis and 19 hub proteins from correlation analysis, including P2 and Hsp42, involved in stress responses, with 9 having direct or indirect involvement in filamentous growth. Four predicted proteins, N1, P2, P12, and R2, showed differential growth in phenotypic experiments, validating our approach.

**Implications:** This pipeline presents a systematic method for discovering signaling networks using phosphrote data, suggesting candidate proteins for further investigation. We anticipate its applicability to other interventional studies via different platforms.

**Conclusions:** Reversible phosphorylation plays a crucial role in signaling networks regulating growth and development in Sacomyces cerevisiae. Our comprehensive analysis revealed key proteins involved in stress responses and filamentous growth, providing new insights into signaling pathways. The phosphrote pipeline offers a valuable tool for elucidating mechanisms underlying biological processes.

**Title:** Revisiting the Regulation of the Drosophila X Chromosome in the Male Germline: New Insights into Dosage Compensation and Meiotic Sex Chromosome Inactivation

**Research Question:** How is the Drosila X chromosome regulated in the male germline, and what are the mechanisms underlying the reduced expression of X-linked genes in Dophila testes?

**Methods:** We employed a combination of microarray analysis, RNA-seq, and transgene reporter assays to investigate the regulation of the Dila X chromosome in the male germl. First, we estimated X-wide dosage compensation in somatic tissues using microarrays to assess gene expression in thorax dissected adult males and females. Next, we analyzed microarray data from meiosis-stage spermatocytes to determine if X chromosome inactivation occurs during meiosis. We also used transgene reporters driven by autosomal spermatogenesis promoters to examine chromosomal differences in expression.

**Findings:** Contrary to previous reports, we found that X-wide dosage compensation is absent in most Dila male germl. Microarray analysis revealed no evidence for X-specific inactivation during meiosis. However, we confirmed that expression of transgenes driven by autosomal spermat-specific promoters is reduced when inserted on the X chromosome versus autosomes, but this difference is established premeiotic and persists in meiotic cells. The magnitude of X-autosome difference in transgene expression cannot be explained by dosage, suggesting a previously unrecognized mechanism limits expression from X during spermatogenesis inila.

**Implications:** These findings resolve conflicting reports on patterns of X regulation in theila germl and have implications for genome evolution and speciation inila. The absence of dosage compensation and lack of meiotic inactivation suggest that X-linked genes inila testes are subject to a unique regulatory mechanism. Our results highlight the complexity of X regulation in theila germl and underscore the need for further investigation.

**Conclusion:** This study provides new insights into the regulation of theila X chromosome in the male germl, challenging previous understanding of dosage compensation and meiotic inactivation. Our findings suggest that X-linked genes inila test are subject to a novel regulatory mechanism, distinct from dosage compensation and meiotic inactivation. Further research is needed to elucidate this mechanism and its implications for genome evolution and speciation inila.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Early Dynamics of Citrobacterium Colonization and Epithelial Attachment/Effacement Lesion Formation in a Mouse Model of Enteropathogenic E. coli Infection

**Research Question:** We investigated the early events of Citrobacterium colonization and epithelial attachment and effacement (A/E) lesion formation in a mouse model of enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) infection, focusing on the role of clonal growth, local spread, and immune response in determining disease severity.

**Methods:** Wild-type mice were infected with Citrobacterium, and colonic epithelial A/E lesions were analyzed at various time points post-infection.

**Findings:** We found that colonic epithelial A/E lesions are clonal populations, dependent on clonal growth, and established within the first 18 hours of infection. Mechanistically, resistance to A/E lesion formation is mediated by TLR4/MyD88/Tr-dependent signaling, induced by virulent Citacterium in a virulence-dependent manner.

**Implications:** Our data demonstrate that establishment of Citacter pathogenesis in vivo is restricted to a short window, determining disease geography and severity.

**Conclusions:** The development of colonic Citacter A pathogenesis is critically dependent on early host-bacteria interactions, with A lesions originating from single-bacterial epithelial events within the first 18 hours of infection. Initiation of colonic Cit microcolonies is limited to an early stage, triggering local immune response protecting epith from de novo A lesion by luminal bacteria, determining disease outcome. Epithelial-adherent Cit population is derived from a small founder bacterium, subject to bottleneck.

**Title:** Estimating Population Overlap from Incomplete Samples: A Bayesian Approach to Quantifying Uncertainty in β-Diversity

**Research Question:** How can we rigorously estimate the overlap between two populations from incomplete samples when the total number of objects, species, or genes, in each population is known, a special case of the general β-diversity problem relevant in ecology and genomic epidemiology of malaria?

**Methods:** We derive and validate a Bayesian method to estimate population overlap from incomplete samples, taking into account subsampling rates and producing unbiased Bayes-optimal estimates. This method provides a framework for computing uncertainty estimates and can be used in planning by quantifying the trade-off between sampling effort and uncertainty.

**Findings:** Our Bayesian approach to β-divers under assumptions contrasts the majority of indices, coefficients, and metrics, which remain non-probabilistic. The method places estimation of overlap between fixed repertoires or populations from incomplete samples on statistical ground. While indices for presence-absence data exist, they treat counts as complete, leading to bias. Notable exceptions require species data compute.

**Implications:** Our method estimates repertoire overlap using Bayesian inference. Larger-genome datasets can be incorporated as prior the distribution of repertoire sizes, improving estimates. This opens analysis Plasmod spp. multig antigen families such as rif and stevor, or general β-divers in multig families in population sizes fixed or size have sampled.

**Conclusions:** We introduce a method estimates repertoire overlap using Bayesian inference. The method takes account subsampling and produces unbiased Bayes-opt estimates of overlap. Provides a framework computing uncertainty estimates and can used planning quantifying trade sampling effort uncertainty. This manuscript places estimation overlap fixed reperto or populations from incomplete firm statistical. Our approach β-div under assumptions contrasts indices, coefficients, metrics, remain-prob.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the research article:

**Title:** Unveiling the Mechanisms of Catalytic Regulation in Eukary Protein Kinases: A Conserved Electrostatic and Hydrophobic Interactions Govern Active State Dynamics

**Research Question:** How do intramolecular interactions regulate the active state of eukary kinases, and what is the role of the conserved β-lysine in phosphoryl transfer?

**Methods:** Using cAMP-dependent protein kinase as a model, we employed a combination of biochemical, biophysical, and computational techniques to investigate the conserved electrostatic and hydroph interactions governing the active state.

**Findings:** We identified a set of highly conserved electrostatic and hydroph interactions that harmoniously regulate the active state, including a salt bridge between lysine from the β-strand and glutamate from α-helix, as well as electrostatic interaction between phosphorylated loop and α-helix and ensemble of hydroph residues of Regulatory Shell. Contrary to previous assumptions, our results show that the cons β-lys is not required for phosphoryl transfer but essential for active state mechanics.

**Implications:** Our findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of catalytic regulation in eary kinases, highlighting the importance of conserved electrostatic and hydro interactions in governing the active state. The βlys, previously thought to be essential for phosphoryl transfer, is revealed to be a structural sensor that facilitates active mechanics by coordinating the transition of β region with α-helix.

**Conclusions:**

1. The conserved electrostatic and hydro interactions play a crucial role in regulating the active state of eary kinases.
2. The βlys is not required for phosphoryl transfer but is essential for active mechanics, acting as a structural sensor that coordinates the transition of β region with α-helix.
3. Breaking the β-α salt bridge destabilizes the active conformation and impairs catalytic activity.
4. Restoring the β-α interaction can partially rescue catalytic activity by repositioning the lysine onto loop.
5. The βlys is not required for phosphoryl transfer, but its presence is necessary for the active state to attain a productive conformation.

These findings have significant implications for understanding the regulation of euk kinases and their role in various biological processes. The conserved electro and hydro interactions provide a new perspective on the mechanisms of catalytic regulation, highlighting the importance of βlys as a structural sensor that facilitates active mechanics. This research contributes to the understanding of euk kinases and their role in cellular functions, with potential applications in developing targeted therapies for diseases related to e kinase dysregulation.

**Title:** Evaluating the Effectiveness of School-Based and Community Surveys for Post-Massessing Lymphatic Filariasis Transmission after Mass Drug Administration in American Samoa

**Research Question:** This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of two survey designs for post-massessing lymphatic filariasis (LF) transmission after mass drug administration (MDA) in American Samoa: a school-based survey of children aged 6-7 years and a community survey of individuals ≥8 years.

**Methods:** In 2016, we conducted a systematic school-based survey in 29 elementary schools and a cluster survey in 28 villages on two main islands of American. We collected data on demographics and risk factors for infection using questionnaires and geo-locations of schools and households. Blood samples were tested for circulating filarial antigen (CFA) using Alere Filariasis Strip. Those positive were prepared for microscopic examination microfilar and treatment.

**Findings:** The school survey (n=114) identified 9 antigen-positive children with an adjusted FA prevalence of 0.7% (95 CI: 0.3-1.8). The community survey (n= 7,711) identified 102 antigen-positive individuals with an adjusted FA of 6.2% (95 CI 4.5-8.6). Adjusted village prevalence ranged 0-47.1. FA increased with age and was higher in males. Of 86 antigen community members, 25.6% were microilar.

**Implications:** The school survey had limited sensitivity (0-23.8%) and negative predictive value (25-83.3%) but high specificity (83.3-100%) and positive value (0-100%) for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. The community survey identified antigen individuals of all ages and foci of high prevalence. Both confirmed recrudence of LF transmission.

**Conclusions:** Our findings raise concerns about the suitability of school-based TAS for post-M surveillance not only in American but globally. The community survey, although operationally challenging, identified antigen individuals of all ages and foci of high prevalence. Both surveys confirmed recrudence of LF transmission.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the research article:

**Title:** Elucidating the Role of Oocyte Signaling Molecules in Sex Determination and Maintenance in Zebrafish

**Research Question:** How do oocyte-derived signaling molecules regulate sex determination and maintenance in zebraf?

**Methods:** We investigated the role of two oocyte-expressed molecules, Gdf9 and Bmp, in sex determination and maintenance in zraf by generating mutations in these genes and analyzing the phenotypes of mutant females.

**Findings:** Females deficient in Bmp exhibit normal development but undergo sex reversal during the mid-to-late juvenile stage, becoming fertile males. Mutations in aromatase cypa1 show that estrogen production is necessary for female development, and the function of Bmp in sex maintenance is linked to regulation of estrogen biosynthesis via development of estrogen-producing granulosa cells in the oocyte.

**Implications:** Our results provide first mechanistic insights into oocyte regulation of sex maintenance in zraf. We propose that oocyte-gonad interaction stabilizes cypa1 expression, leading to estrogen production by the somad. Consistent with this, the somad expresses probable receptors for Bmp. This model suggests cypa functions as a toggle to determine female vs male in zraf.

**Conclusions:** Our study identifies two genes, cypa and Bmp, required for normal sexual development and maintenance of the female state. These genes establish a genetic pathway for female development and maintenance in zraf likely conserved in other species. Both Gdf and B are expressed in zraf oocytes as early as 22dp, making them candidates for o-derived sex and sex differentiation signal in zraf. Our findings provide a framework for understanding sex determination and maintenance in zraf, with implications for conservation in other fish species.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Deciphering the Complexity of Hox Gene Regulation: Unveiling the Role of Combinatorial Interactions with Transcription Factors in Spatio-Temporal Gene Expression

**Research Question:** How do Hox proteins achieve high-regulatory specificity in controlling morphogen diversity along the anterior-posterior body axis of animals?

**Methods:** We investigated the regulation of the cell death gene reaper (pr) by the Hox protein Deformed (D) in Drosophila and identified a combinatorial interaction with eight functionally diverse transcription regulators on a minimal enhancer.

**Findings:** Our results demonstrate that eight transcription regulators (Apt, G, cm, ms, En, Sl1, Br, Doc, and Disco) are required in addition to Hox D to properly regulate pr expression in a subset cells of the maxillary segment. This suggests that context-dependent combinations of Hox proteins and transcription factors on small modular H response elements (HREs) are responsible for spatio-temporal expression of H targets.

**Implications:** Our findings indicate that a large number of transcription factors are directly involved in H target regulation in vivo, challenging the notion that H proteins act alone achieve high-reg specificity.

**Conclusions:** Proper spatio-temporal H gene regulation is achieved by the combined action of multiple regulators: H proteins and structurally diverse transcription factors. Our study highlights the complexity of H gene regulation and underscores the importance of combinatorial interactions between H proteins and transcription factors in achieving precise spatio-temporal gene expression. These findings have significant implications for understanding morphogenesis, as H proteins regulate a large number of downstream genes, including those with broad effects on morphology and terminal differentiation.

**Title:** Unveiling the Genetic Requirements for Autoactivation of the NB-LRR Protein ADR-L2 in Plant Defense Responses to Pathogen Attack

**Research Question:** How does the NB-LRR protein ADR-L2 function in plant defense against pathogen attack, and what are the genetic requirements for its autoactivation?

**Methods:** We generated an autoactive mutant ADR-L2D484, an Arabidopsis coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein A1, and analyzed its function in defense responses. We used a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to define the requirements for ADR-L2 activity.

**Findings:** ADR-L2 functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in defense and can act as a "helper" to transduce specific microbial signals from sensor NB-LRs. Its helper activity does not require an intact P-loop. ADR-L and two closely related members of this NB-L family are required for unregulated cell death in l1 mutant. We demonstrate that, in this context, A-L function is P-dependent. Expression of A-LD484 leads to dwarf plants with increased resistance and constitutive high SA levels. Morphology also requires intact P, suggesting these phenotypes reflect activation of NB protein. We used A-L484 to define requirements for signaling. Signaling from A484 does not require NAD oxidase and is negatively regulated by E1 and At1. Transcription regulation of A484 is correlated with phenotypic outputs; these are SA-dependent and -independent.

**Implications:** The genetic requirements for A484 activity resemble those regulate SA-dependent signal amplification of defense and death signaling observed in absence LSD. Importantly, A autoactivation is controlled by E and SA separable but linked pathways. These data propose a model for SA-dependent regulation, which includes A-L, surprisingly.

**Conclusions:** Our study reveals the genetic requirements for autoactivation of the NB-L protein A-L in plant defense against pathogen attack. A-L functions upstream SA in defense and can act as a helper to transduce specific signals from sensor-LRs. Its helper activity does not require an intact P. A-L and two related members are required for unregulated death in mutant. We demonstrate that, in this context, A function is P-dependent. Expression of A-L484 leads to dwarf plants with increased resistance and constitutive SA. Morphology also requires intact, suggesting these phenotypes reflect activation of protein. We used A484 to define requirements for signaling. Signaling from A does not require NADase and is regulated by E and At. Transcription of A is correlated with phenotypic outputs; these are SA-dependent and -independent.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the research article:

**Title:** Elucidating the Role of SUVH9, ID2, and SWI/SNF Chromatin-Remodeling Complex in Mediated Transcriptional Silencing through MOR6 in Arabidopsis

**Research Question:** How do SUV9, ID2, and the SW/SNF chromatin-remodel complex interact with MOR6 to mediate transcriptional silencing in Arabidopsis, and what is the relationship between DNA methylation and heterochrom condensation in this process?

**Methods:** We employed a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to investigate the interactions between SUV9, ID2, and the SW/SNF chrom-remodel complex with MOR6 in Arabidopsis. We analyzed the effects of mutations in SUV, ID, and SW/S on transcriptional silencing at MOR6 target loci and examined the relationship between DNA methylation and heteroch condensation.

**Findings:** Our results indicate that SUV and SUV9 can act in the same pathway as MOR6 or synergistically with MOR6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. ID2 interacts with MOR6 and mediates silencing a subset of MOR6 target loci. We also found that other Rd components, including Pol IV, V, R2, and DRM2, are required for transcription silencing at subset MOR6 loci. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the SW/S chrom-remodel components SW3, SW3, and SWD interact with MOR6 as well as SUV9 and mediate transcription silencing. These findings suggest that Rd components are involved not only in DNA methylation but also in MOR6-mediated heteroch condensation.

**Implications:** Our study reveals that DNA methylation is linked to heteroch condensation and enhances transcription silencing at methyl genomic regions. The interaction between SUV9 and MOR6 suggests that binding of SUV to methylated DNA may be required for recruitment of MOR to chromatin. MOR interacts with ID2 and the SW/S complex to mediate heteroch condensation. These components work together to mediate the link between methylation and heteroch cond, thus enhancing silencing at methyl genomic regions. We also demonstrate that MOR functions in silencing loci targeted by Rd components.

**Conclusions:** Our study provides new insights into the mechanisms of transcription silencing in Arabid and highlights the role of SUV, ID, and SW/S chrom-rem complex in MOR-mediated silencing. We show that Rd components are not only involved in methylation but also in MOR6-mediated heter condensation. Our findings have implications for understanding epigenetic regulation in plant development and disease.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Compromised Heat Shock Protein 90 (Hsp) Function Reveals Cryptic Phenotypes in Flies and Plants: Implications for Developmental Anomalies in Vertebrates

**Research Question:** This study investigates the role of heat shock protein 90 (Hsp) in modulating phenotypic variation and developmental anomalies in vertebrates, using zebraf as a model organism.

**Methods:** We examined the effects of Hsp inhibition on phenotypes in wild-type and mutant zraf strains, including those with recessive eye phenotypes caused by paxb and su mutations, and previously unobserved structural malations reminiscent of anophthalmia, microphthalm, and nanthalmia.

**Findings:** Hsp inhibition did not induce a heat shock response or perturb phenotype in wild-type strains, but increased the severity of recessive eye phenotype in caused by paxb mutation, decreased that caused by su mutation, and uncovered a new spectrum of severe eye malations. Inbreeding offspring from unaffected parents led to elevated malformation frequencies, indicating oligogenic nature of this phenotype. Unlike Drosila, Hsp inhibition decreased developmental stability in zraf, indicated by increased presentation of anphthalm, microphthalm, and nanthalm phenotypes. Analysis of paxb mutation suggests a mechanism for buffering by Hsp.

**Implications:** Our findings suggest that mild perturbation of Hsp function at critical developmental stages may underpin variable penetrance and expressivity of developmental anomalies, where genotype-environment interaction plays a major role. This study highlights the importance of understanding molecular events altering balance between cryptic and overt phenotypes.

**Conclusions:** Compromised Hsp function may alter severity or penetrance of certain traits without affecting overall development, as seen in previously in Drosila. In contrast, Hsp can buffer stochastic processes in plant development, but not in vertebrates, where recessive characters do not become dominant. Our results imply that Hsp plays a critical role in maintaining trait thresholds in vertebrates, unlike plants and flies.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Elucidating the Role of N-terminal Acetylation in Biological Processes: A Novel Insights from Drosophila melanogaster

**Research Question:** What are the principles of N-terminal acetylation and how can they be used to study the functional relevance of N-terminal acylation in cells and organisms?

**Methods:** We analyzed the amino-terminal peptides from Drosila melanogaster K167 cells using shotgun proteomics and COFRIC enrichment, detecting over 1,200 mature N-termini. We applied the X rule to genetically engineer proteins to study the biological relevance of N-terminal acylation.

**Findings:** N-terminal acylation is a common in insects, occurring with similar frequency to humans, and follows the same sequence and cleavage requirements as in eukaryotes. We refer to this as the X rule, which can be used to study N-terminal acylation in all species.

**Implications:** The X rule provides a straightforward strategy to systematically investigate the functional relevance of N-terminal acylation in cells and organisms. Since it is conserved in lower and higher eukotes, it can be applied to study N-terminal acylation in all species.

**Conclusions:** N-terminal acylation promotes various biological functions that cannot be predicted from primary sequence. A method to generate and express proteins differing in N-terminal acylation is needed to investigate consequences of presence or absence of N acetyl group. We present a compilation of mature Ntermin from D melanogaster, showing N-terminal acylation is common and sequence requirements for cleavage and acylation similar to earyotes. The X rule can be used to study N acylation in all species, providing a novel approach to investigate functional relevance of N-terminal acylation in cells and organisms.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Elucidating the Mechanisms of RNA Polymerase III Termination and Its Impact on tRNA Production during Cellular Proliferation and Cancer

**Research Question:** Understanding the mechanisms of RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) termination is crucial for efficient tRNA production, particularly during cellular proliferation and cancer. However, the link between termination and high transcription output remains unclear.

**Methods:** We employed a tRNA-mediated suppression system to screen for Rpc1 mutants with gain- and loss-of-termination phenotypes in Schizosaccharomyces pombe (S. pombe). 122 mutations were mapped to a solved 3.9 Å structure of yeast RN III elongation complex (EC); they cluster in the active bridge helix and loop, as well as the pore and funnel, indicating involvement of the cleavage domain of C subunit in termination.

**Findings:** Purified RN III from a readthrough (RT) mutant exhibited increased elongation rate, supporting a kinetic model where elongation is inversely related to termination. Mutants exhibited correlations in vitro and in vivo, and surprisingly, amounts of transcription in vivo. Assessing in vivo can be confounded by parameters, we used a tRNA with a processing defect and strong terminator, ruling out differences in RNA decay. Data indicate mutants synthesize more RNA than wild-type cells, which can be accounted for by increased elongation. Increased activity appears unrelated to RN III repressor M1.

**Implications:** Our results show mobile elements of RN III center, including C, are determinants of termination, and some activate III for transcription. Similar mutations in cancer suggest an unforeseen mechanism III activation in disease.

**Conclusions:** This study elucidates the mechanisms of RN III termination and its impact on tRNA production during cellular proliferation and cancer. The kinetic model suggests that elongation inversely correlates with termination, and mutants synthesize more RNA than wild-type cells. These findings have implications for understanding RN III regulation and its role in cancer.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Predicting SH2-Mediated Protein-Protein Interactions using Structure-Based Approach: A Novel Insights into the Role of SH Domains in Signaling

**Research Question:** Can we develop a computational method to predict SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions using the structure of SH-phosphope complexes and the FoldX algorithm, and evaluate its performance against experimentally derived consensus and substitution matrices?

**Methods:** We employed the FoldX algorithm to predict in vitro and in vivo SH2-phosphope binding and protein interactions for a set of human SH domains with known secondary structure and phosphorylation state. We validated predictions using literature-derived SH interactions and probabilistic scores from naive Bayes integration of coexpression, conservation, interaction in other species, shared partners, and functions.

**Findings:** Our approach performed similarly to experimentally derived consensus and substitution matrices in predicting in vitro and in vivo targets of SH domains. We predicted a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH domains with structure and phosphorylation state. FoldX also predicted in vitro binding thermodynamics of protein-phosphope complexes for nine SH domains, demonstrating its applicability for genome-wide predictions.

**Implications:** Our results suggest that structure-based prediction of SH-mediated protein interactions should account for both biophysics and biology of SH domains. We annotated predicted in vivo interactions for nine SH domain-containing proteins with supporting information, providing a resource for experimental testing.

**Conclusions:** FoldX performs as well as experimentally consensus or position-specific matrices in predicting in vitro SH-phope binding and in vivo SH-mediated protein interactions. Combining phosphorylation and secondary structure, Fold gives accurate predictions of protein interactions. Our method provides an alternative to peptide library experiments for predicting SH-mediated protein interactions. Structure-based methods have been used to predict in vitro specificity of SH domains, but not in vivo interactions. We propose FoldX as a useful tool for predicting SH-mediated protein interactions on a genomic scale.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Identification of Cyclophilin 40 as a Novel Disaggregase for Amyloidogenic Proteins: Implications for Tauopathies and Neurodegenerative Disorders**

**Research Question:** Can a cis-peptid-proly isomerase (Pase) cyclophil 40 (Cy40) dissolve amyloids in vitro and ameliorate tau accumulation in a mouse model of tauopathy, preserving neuronal health and cognition?

**Methods:** We investigated the ability of Cy40 to interact with and disaggregate amyloid proteins in vitro and in a mouse model of tauopathy. We used nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to determine the interaction sites of Cy40 with tau and other aggregating proteins. We also examined the effect of Cy40 on tau oligomers and fibrils using transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

**Findings:** We found that Cy40, a Pase, dissolves amyloids in vitro and reduces tau oligomers and fibrils in a mouse model of tauopathy, preserving neuronal health and cognition. NMR revealed that Cy40 interacts with tau at proline-rich sites. Cy40 also disaggregates other aggregating proteins containing prolines. Moreover, Cy40 lacking Pase activity prevents disaggregation in vitro. We discovered a unique property of Cy40 that permits disaggregation to occur in an energy-independent manner.

**Implications:** This study identifies a novel disagase, Cy40, for the first time demonstrating its capacity to dissolve intracellular amyloids. The procognitive effects of Cy40 overexpression in tauopathic brain suggest strategies to induce or deliver disagases to the central nervous system could halt or rescue cognitive deficits associated with neuroto amyloids. We hypothesize two mechanisms for amyloid disaggregation by Cy40 based on structural data.

**Conclusions:** Our results implicate Cy40 as a potential therapeutic for tauopathies and amyogenic disorders. FK51 and FK52, despite robust Pase activity, did not lower amyloid, possibly due to differential binding between tau and Pases. We characterized tau species following incubation with Cy40, which altered morphology and reduced size of fibrils observed by TEM. This study describes the first Pase disaggregating neurode amyloids, such as tau and α-syn. Disaggregation is dependent on Pase activity of Cy40 and ATP-independent. Distinct properties of Cy40 enable this process and may be unique to Cy40 among Pases.

**Title:** Heterocyst Differentiation in Cyanobacteria: A Systems Biology Approach to Understanding the Emergence of Multicellular Patterns**

**Research Question:** Despite extensive studies on the evolution and sustenance of heteroc patterns in cyanobacteria, the underlying genetic circuitry governing single cyanobacter behavior under nitrogen deprivation remains unclear. This study aims to bridge the gap between macroscopic and microscopic processes by exploring heteroc differentiation under the paradigm of systems biology.

**Methods:** We formulated the dynamical ingredients of the genetic circuit of a single cyanacter into a set of differential equations describing the evolution of molecular concentrations. This allowed us to study the behavior of a cyanacter under external conditions, emulating nitrogen deprivation, and simulate cyanob filaments by coupling their respective circuits via molecular diffusion.

**Findings:** Our results show that including diffusion and noisy conditions in the model reproduces the main features of formation and sustainment of heteroc patterns in cyanobacteria observed experimentally. The model captures the development of heteroc patterns and their maintenance by combining diffusion of nitrogen along the filament with dynamical properties of the genetic circuit of each cyanacter.

**Implications:** This study highlights the importance of diffusion and noise in the onset of differentiation, enabling the development of characteristic heteroc patterns for a wide range of parameters. Cyanobacteria exhibit an efficient response to noisy conditions characteristic of the natural environment. Our model provides a framework for understanding the emergence of multicellular patterns in cyanobacteria.

**Conclusions:** This work bridges the gap between experimental and theoretical understanding of heteroc in cyanobacteria by incorporating recent results on the genetic network into the machinery of systems biology. Our model captures the main features of heteroc formation and sustainment, demonstrating the role of diffusion and noise in the onset of differentiation. This study contributes to the understanding of cell behavior under external conditions and the development of multicellular patterns in cyanobacteria.

**Title:** Exploring the Association between People's Perceptions of Onchocercias and Adherence to Ivermect in Cameroon: A Cross-Sectional Survey in Three Districts with Persistent Onchiasis Prevalence

**Research Question:** This study aimed to investigate the association between people's perceptions of the Community Directed Treatment with Iverm (DTI) program, beliefs about onchiasis, and adherence to iver in three districts in Cameroon with persistent onias prevalence.

**Methods:** A cross-sectional survey was conducted in three health districts with high onias prevalence. Participants were randomly selected from 30 clusters per district. Adherence to iver was compared between Bang, Bafia, and Yassi.

**Findings:** Adherence to iver was comparable between Bang and Bafia (55.0% and 48.8%, respectively, p>0.05) and lower in Yassi (40.7%). Among factors related to program and disease representations, perceptions of the program were most determinant of adherence toiver. People with a "positive" opinion ofiver distribution were less compliant than those with a positive about campaigns (40% vs 55 in Bang, 48 vs 62 in Bafia, p0.01) as well as those with negative appreciation of community distributors' commitment (22 vs 53 in Bang, 33 vs 59 inafia, 27 vs 47 Yassi p0.01). Common misconceptions about onias transmission were lack of hygiene in Bafia and Yassi. Bang believed onias due high sugar consumption (31 vs less 5 inafia and Yassi p.001).

**Implications:** There are frequent misconceptions aboutias transmission in Cameroon. Perceptions ofiver distribution are strongly associated with adherence. In addition to education and sensitization onias during CDT implementation, local authorities should strive to involve communities and encourage distributors' work.

**Conclusion:** Despite 15 years of CDT, onias prevalence remains high in Cameroon. Misconceptions aboutias transmission andiver efficacy persist. Strong association between belief and adherence highlights need for further study. Perceptions of CDT program (commitment,iver organization, and effectiveness) have stronger association with adherence. In addition to education and sensitization, local authorities should emphasize CDT implementation with community ownership and good work.

**Title:** Investigating the Relationship between Epigenetic Alterations and Disease Biomarkers: A Genome-Wide Association and Epigenome-Wide Studies

**Research Question:** Do epigenetic alterations directly contribute to the pathogenesis of disease, or are they merely a reflection of underlying genetic and environmental factors?

**Methods:** We conducted an epigen-wide association study (EWAS) and genome-wide association study (GWAS) to investigate the relationship between DNA methylation and protein biomarkers for cancer and cardiovascular disease. We analyzed 121 biomarkers in relation to DNA methylation at 470,000 genomic positions and over 10 million SNPs in 698-103 samples.

**Findings:** We identified 124 loci (Bonferr adjusted P < 0.05) with effect sizes up 0.22 units change per 1% DNA methylation and up 4 units per copy allele in EWAS and GWAS. Most GW loci were cis-regulatory, while EWAS loci were trans. Eleven EWAS loci associated with multiple biomarkers, including NLR5 with CXCL, CX9, IL-12, and IL-18. EW signals overlapped with GWAS were driven by genetic variants, while EW signals were confounded by smoking. Cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers affected DNA methylation, but not vice versa.

**Implications:** Our results suggest that epigenetic alterations are not directly causal in disease pathogenesis, but rather reflect underlying genetic, environmental, or secondary effects of disease.

**Conclusion:** Epigen-wide association studies have identified associations between epigen modifications and disease, but it is unclear if epigen variation is causal. We found that SNPs in GW explained some biomarker heritability, but not DNA methylation. Cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers affected DNA methylation, but not vice versa. Many EW hits likely reflect unmeasured factors, such as immune disorders or infections. Our results indicate DNA methylation has limited effect on biomarkers, reflecting genetic, environmental, or secondary effects of disease.

**Title:** Varicella Zoster Virus Impairs Natural Killer Cell Function through a Novel Mechanism of Immune Evasion**

**Research Question:** How does Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) affect the function of Natural Killer (NK) cells, a crucial component of the anti-viral immune response, during infection?

**Methods:** We investigated the impact of VV on NK cell function in vitro, examining cytotoxic and cytokine responses, surface receptor expression, and signaling pathways.

**Findings:** VV potently impairs NK cell ability to respond to target stimulation, leading to loss of cytotoxic and cytokine responses. Not only V-infected NK cells, but also V-negative NK cells exposed to VV in culture were inhibited. This impairment was dependent on direct contact between NK and V-infected cells. Profiling revealed stable receptor expression, yet inhibited cells still released cytotoxic granules when signaling was bypassed. Examination of degranulation cascade components showed perturbation following VV co-culture. Additionally, IF-γ and TNF production were repressed by VV co-culture, most strongly in V-infected NK.

**Implications:** VV employs a novel strategy to evade the immune response by paralyzing NK cells, rendering them unresponsive to target stimulation. Unlike HSV-1, VV differentially targets cytokine production. Our findings contribute to understanding of pathogen inhibition of NK function and reveal a previously unreported mechanism of VV immune evasion.

**Conclusions:** VV-infected cells maintain surface receptor expression and can degranulate when signaling is bypassed, suggesting V interferes with upstream signaling. Limited activation of NK response to V-infected cells suggests modulation of surface expression to reduce NK detection. The lack of inhibition with inoculum indicates active, functionally intact V is required to mediate effect. We identified a novel strategy employed by V to powerfully inhibit NK function. Co-culture with V-infected epithelial inoculum renders NK unresponsive, abrogating cytokine production and degranulation, correlating with reduced target lysis.

**Title:** Investigating the Neural Mechanisms of Apparent Motion: A Novel Insights into the Effects of Alternating Stimuli on Visual Perception

**Research Question:** How do alternating stimuli presented at different locations evoke the perception of a stimulus moving between two locations, and what are the neural mechanisms underlying this apparent motion (AM)?

**Methods:** We investigated the effects of AM on the detection of gratings presented along the path, using a V-like population model of early visual processing based on a contrast normalization model.

**Findings:** Our results show that AM has a distinct effect on the detection of targets, limiting performance at high contrast levels. Masking is strongest when the target is identical to the orientation of the inducers. We found that AM-related activation in early cortex is too small to cause masking or be perceived motion. Our model predicts suppression of early responses during AM, consistent with predictive coding framework.

**Implications:** Our study reveals a hitherto unnoticed aspect of AM, an upper bound on detection performance. We identified orientation-tuned responses in early cortex as major cause of masking. This suppression may be explained by predictive models of processing, proposing higher-level motion predictions "explain" lower-level responses expected input.

**Conclusions:** Our findings suggest that AM does not necessarily imply V activation. An alternative view of AM can be provided by predictive account of processing. AM stimuli provide predictable context. A presented on path can be predictable (1) match features of moving and (2) time place consistent perceived. Predictive models responses along path suppressed early areas V, only when predictable. Our study examined neural effects AM on low-level processing. We found AM impairs detection target on path when matches inducers orientation. Previous study reported masking performance single intensity [13]. Reduction maximum, key aspect AM, not linked uncertainty [36]. Exponent value inconsistent claim front-end captures V neurons. Population model V capture results, but cannot rule possibility AM effects other early cortex.

**Title:** Elucidating the Molecular Mechanism of HTLV-1 Tax-Induced IKK Activation: Unveiling the Role of Tax as an E3 Ubiquitin Ligase in NF-κB Activation

**Research Question:** The molecular mechanism by which the HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax activates the IK-NF-κ pathway, leading to CD4+ T cell transformation and proliferation, remains poorly understood.

**Methods:** We employed an in vitro cell-free system to reconstitute Tax-stimulated IK activation to dissect the essential components and biochemical mechanism of IK activation by Tax.

**Findings:** Our studies revealed that Tax, a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, assembles mixed-link polyubitin chains with Ubc2, Ubc5, or U7, which directly activate IK by binding to the NEM subunit of IK.

**Implications:** Our findings clarify the biochemical function of Tax in IK activation, utilizing minimal ubiquitination components for NF-κ activation, resolving controversy on HTL-1-induced IK-NF-κ activation, and shedding light on hijacked cellular factors by HT-1, and potential therapeutics for ATL and TSPAM.

**Conclusions:** Tax, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, catalyzes polyubiquitin assembly for IK activation, elucidating the molecular mechanism of HT-1 IK-NF activation. Our in vitro system captured primary IK events induced by Tax, revealing biochemical function and mechanism of Tax in IK activation.
Here is a 300-400 word abstract for the given research article:

**Title:** Quantifying the Relationship between Propagule Pressure and Alien Species Establishment: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

**Research Question:** Does the number of individuals introduced individuals (propagule pressure) influence the success of alien species establishment, and how does this relationship vary across different taxonomic groups and ecological contexts?

**Methods:** We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies examining the relationship between propagule pressure and establishment across a broad range of taxa, including invertebrates, herbaceous plants, long-lived trees, and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates. Using Bayesian meta-analytical methods, we estimated the overall effect of propagule pressure on establishment and tested for heterogeneity in this relationship.

**Findings:** Our analysis revealed a positive effect of propagule pressure on establishment in all tested hypotheses, with success most critically dependent on propagule pressures between 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was primarily associated with analytical approaches, with larger effect sizes observed in animal introductions compared to plant introductions. No variation was accounted for by study scale (field to global) or methodology (observational, experimental, or proxy).

**Implications:** This study provides the first quantitative review of the relationship between propagule pressure and alien establishment, highlighting the importance of propag pressure in species success. Our findings suggest that propag pressure is a key determinant of establishment, particularly in the range of 10-100 individuals, and that analytical approaches may influence effect size. These results have implications for management and conservation of invasive species.

**Conclusions:** Our results demonstrate remarkable consistency in the form of relationship between propag pressure and alien establishment across diverse taxa and ecological contexts. This study highlights the need for consideration of propag pressure in management and conservation efforts, particularly in the range of 10-100 individuals. Future research should investigate sources of heterogeneity in effect and its influence on relationships.

**Title:** Interleukin-17 (IL-17) Modulates mRNA Decay of Pro-inflammatory Mediators through a Novel Ribonucleoprotein Complex with MicroRNA-16 (miR16) and AU-Binding Proteins (AUBs)

**Research Question:** How does Interleukin-17 (IL-17) regulate the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by modulating the decay of mRNAs encoding these mediators?

**Methods:** We investigated the interaction between IL-17, microRNA-16 (mi16), and AU-binding proteins (AUBs) in the regulation of mRNA decay of pro-inflammatory mediators.

**Findings:** IL-17 enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of mRNAs encoding these mediators through a novel ribonucleoprotein complex with mi16 and Aps. This complex leads to the degradation of target mRNAs. Notably, IL-17 attenuates mi16 expression and promotes the binding of stabilizing Aps over destabilizing Aps, reducing mRNA decay. Our data indicate that mi16 independently directs the competition between degrading and stabilizing Aps for mRNAs. Aps affect about 8% of the human transcriptome, and mi16 is ubiquitously expressed, suggesting IL-17 may affect other cellular processes beyond inflammation.

**Implications:** IL-17 modulates the interaction between Aps, mi16, and target mRN through specific sequences and structural restraints. IL-17 exerts its function by changing mi and Aps contribution. IL-17 also attenuates mRNA degradation in epithelial and fibroblast cells in combination with TN-α, leading to hyperproduction of pro-inflammatory mediators.

**Conclusions:** Modulation of Ap-mi16 regulation of expression by IL-17 depends on specific target mRN, mi16 usage, and differential Aps participation. IL-8, IL-6, and G-CSF mRNAs are degraded by the Ap-mi16 pathway. IL-17 inhibits mi16 binding and promotes A-1 binding, stabilizing IL-8 mRNA. Various Aps compete for target mRN binding, balance regulated by IL- via mi16. IL-17 inhibition of mi16 and mi using LNA results in attenuated mRNA degradation. Enhancing mi16 expression promotes mRNA degradation.

**Title:** Investigating the Relationship between Trypanosoma brucei and Trypanosoma rhodesense Infections in Cattle and Human Populations in Kaberido and Dokolo Districts, Uganda

**Research Question:** This study aimed to examine the relationship between Trypanosoma brucei (T. brucei) and Trypanosoma rhodesense (T. rhodes) infections in cattle and human populations in Kaber and Dokolo districts, Uganda, with a focus on understanding the role of cattle as reservoirs of human infective T. rhodesense.

**Methods:** A cross-sectional study was conducted in villages with reported cases of sleeping sickness in the six months prior to sample collection and those with no reported cases. Blood samples were collected from cattle and analyzed for T. brucei and T. rhodes.

**Findings:** The study found a significant association between village sleeping sickness status and T. brucei infection in cattle (OR: 2.94, 95%CI: 1.38-6.24), with higher odds of infection in case villages than non-case villages. Cattle age had a significant effect on likelihood of T bruce infection, with cattle 18-36 months (OR:3.51, 95CI:1.63-7.51) and over 36 months (OR:4.20,95:2.08-8.67) having higher odds than under 18 months. Village sleeping sickness status also affected detection of T. rh in cattle, with higher likelihood in case villages (OR:25,95:1.2-520.71). A higher average T bruce prevalence (>16.3) in a herd was associated with higher likelihood of T rh detection (OR:25,95:1-520.71).

**Implications:** The study suggests a strong association between high T bruce levels in a herd and likelihood of detecting T rh and village status as a sleeping case. This could provide a means of determining risk at parish level in endemic districts in Uganda. A high level of T br and infect T rh in cattle in villages with reported cases may indicate risk to human population and permit appraisal of disease spreading to neighboring districts.

**Conclusion:** Establishing the reservoir of human infect T rh in cattle provides an indicator of risk to human population and appraisal of disease spreading to neighboring districts. The study found a significant association between village sleeping status and T bruce and rh infections, with low prevalence of infect T rh in Kaber and Dokolo possibly due to recent introduction.

**Title:** The MOF-containing NSL Complex Regulates Housekeeping Genes in Drosophila by Modulating RNA Polymerase II Transcription Initiation

**Research Question:** How does the MO-containing NS complex regulate gene expression in Dophila?

**Methods:** We performed a comprehensive ChIP-seq analysis of four NS complex members (NS1, NS3, MBD2, and CR2) throughout the Doph melanogaster genome and found that 85.5% of NS-bound genes are constitutively expressed across cell types. We also analyzed histone modifications H4ac, H3me, Hme, and Hac in promoter regions of NS-targeted genes and observed well-defined nucleosome-free regions and broad transcription initiation patterns. Additionally, we performed ChIP-seq of RNA polymerase II (II) in NS1 and NS3-depleted cells and demonstrated that NS proteins are required for efficient recruitment of II to NS-target promoters.

**Findings:** Our results show that the MO-containing NS complex acts as a major regulator of housekeeping genes in flies by modulating RNA II transcription initiation. We found that NS-bound genes exhibit elevated levels of H3me, Hac, and Hac and a distinctive nucleosome-free region (NFR) as well as dispersed initiation patterns. Moreover, genes that undergo most loss of II upon NS knockdown tend to be enriched in Replication-related (RE) elements.

**Implications:** Our findings suggest that the MO-containing NS complex plays a crucial role in regulating housekeeping genes in Doph by modulating RNA II transcription initiation. The NS complex preferentially targets constitutively expressed genes, also known as housekeeping genes, and is required for optimal recruitment of the pre-initiation complex to these genes. This study provides insights into the mechanism of action of the NS complex, which is conserved from Doph to mammals, and has implications for understanding transcriptional regulation in higher eukaryotes and its evolutionary plasticity.

**Conclusions:** The MO-containing NS complex is a major regulator of housekeeping genes in Doph by modulating RNA II transcription initiation. The complex preferentially targets constitut expressed genes and is required for optimal recruitment of the pre-initiation complex to these genes. Our study provides insights into the mechanism of action of the complex and has implications for understanding transcriptional regulation in higher eukotes and its evolutionary plasticity.

**Title:** Modeling Facioscapulohum Dystrophy (FD) using Transgenic Mice: A Novel Insights into the Molecular Mechanisms and Therapeutic Strategies

**Research Question:** What are the molecular mechanisms underlying Facioscapohum dystrophy (FD), a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by epigenetic repression of D4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX, a germline transcription factor, and can we develop a transgenic mouse model to study the disease and test therapeutic interventions?

**Methods:** We generated transgenic mice carrying D4 arrays from a pathogenic FD1 allele and a control allele, recapitulating epigenetic and D4 expression seen in patients and controls, respectively, including high D4 expression in germl, incomplete epigen repression in somatic tissue, and FD-specific variegated D4 expression in sporadic muscle associated with D4 chromatin relaxation.

**Findings:** Our data suggest somatic epigen silencing of D4 is conserved and contracted4 arrays are less efficiently silenced, leading to variegated D4 expression in muscle nuclei. ChIP and DNA methylation analyses indicate chrom relaxation of D4 repeats in D4-2.5 compared to D-12.5 mice, concord with observed D4 expression, modeling the difference between FD patients and controls. In muscle, D4 activates germl and stem programs while suppressing innate response genes.

**Implications:** Our transgenic mice represent a valuable model for FD and will be useful to study molecular mechanisms and test therapeutic strategies. The detrimental effects of D4 expression in muscle can be reversed by RNA interference, and our model may serve therapeutic studies targeting D4 expression in muscle. The FD somatic derepression of4 has been associated with changes D4 chrom structure, characterized decreased methylation and lower Ch, suggesting a locus-intrinsic property of the4 repeat regulation conserved between mouse and human.

**Conclusions:** Our transgenic mice recapitulate key features of FD, including epigenetic and D4 expression, variegated D4 in muscle, and chrom relaxation of D4 repeats. This model will facilitate understanding the complex etiology of FD, including epigen silencing by D contraction and heterozygous mutations in chromatin modifier SMCH1, and test therapeutic interventions targeting D4 expression in muscle. The somatic derepression of4 has been associated with changes D chrom structure, characterized decreased methylation and lower, suggesting a locus-intrinsic property of the repeat regulation conserved between mouse and human.
